qas.question: What do older computers have to have in order for USB mice and keyboards to be used?

answers.text: PS/2 connectors with the aid of a small USB-to-PS/2 adapter

qas.question: What is the hardware designed to detect in USB mice and keyboards?

answers.text: whether it is connected to a USB or PS/2 port

qas.question: USB keyboards and mice may communicate using what?
What connects PS/2 keyboards and mice to a USB port?
What performs bidirectional data translation between two standards?

context: USB mice and keyboards can usually be used with older computers that have <a0_0>PS/2 connectors with the aid of a small USB-to-PS/2 adapter<a0_0/>. For mice and keyboards with dual-protocol support, an adaptor that contains no logic circuitry may be used: the hardware in the USB keyboard or mouse is designed to detect <a1_0>whether it is connected to a USB or PS/2 port<a1_0/>, and communicate using the <a2_0>appropriate protocol<a2_0/>. <a3_0>Converters<a3_0/> also exist that connect PS/2 keyboards and mice (usually one of each) to a USB port. These devices present two HID endpoints to the system and use <a4_0>a microcontroller<a4_0/> to perform bidirectional data translation between the two standards.
